// Cat Diseases Descriptions
Cancer in cats is the leading cause of death among cats. It is caused by uncontrolled cell growth, and affects a wide range of cell types and organs in the body. Feline cancer initially manifests as a lump or bump on any parts of the body.
A Biopsy is a surgical procedure in which a piece of tumor is removed for study and analysis by a pathologist. The pathologist`s report will provide important information such as the type of cancer and its characteristics.
Combinations of survey, radiography, abdominal ultrasonography, serial clinical pathology tests, including urinalysis and urine cultures, and blood pressures should be performed to evaluate the severity of the disease.
One common type of cancer in cats is Skin Cancer. Limiting your cat`s exposure to blazing heat can prevent it from catching skin cancer.
Breast cancer is also a common cancer for cats, but having your cat spayed can prevent it from getting this type of cancer.
Kidney disease is a disease that if left untreated, can cause death in cats. Kidney disease is where your cat`s kidney are not properly working. This means that their kidney cannot filter blood as it is supposed to, a number of problem will arise if this disease is ignored.
There are a number of kidney disease medications to give to your cat, but having a veterinarian check up on your cat first is the first thing to do if you think your cat is sick.
If you suspect that your cat have Kidney Disease, take it to your vet and run a number of test such as Urine Tests, Ultrasound, and biopsy (if your vet says it is necessary).
A kidney diet is low in both phosphorus and protein, and is enriched with vitamin D and Omega-3 fatty acids. Remember that it is important ti introduce your cat to new foods gradually. Your vet can advise how to make this transition an easy one.
Giving your cat access to clean water can save it the trouble from getting kidney disease. And with water, your cat can urinate regularly, but not excessively.
Feline Immunodefficiency Virus is one of the most common and consequential diseases of cats around the world. In infected cats, FIV attacks the immune system, leaving the cat vulnerable to many other infections.
Although Cats infected with FIC may appear normal for years, they eventually suffer from immune defficiency, which allows normally harmless bacteria, viruses, and fungi found in everyday environment to potentially cause severe illnesses.
Vaccination will always be a priority; before your cats even get FIV, it should be vaccinated. Although the vaccine will not protect all cats, your cat is better safe than sorry. Don`t take chances.
The most effective treatment for this illness is a regular visit to your vet. Having you vet check up on your cat`s condition will help your cat recover, even bit-by-bit.
Treating secondary infections with the help of your vet will prevent your cat`s condition to worsen. Secondary infections such as wounds and intestinal parasites should be controlled as to help your cat.
A balanced diet will further improve your cat`s condition and health, it will invigorate your cat and make it happy.
Because of FIV, your cat`s immune system will weaken; making your cat vulnerable to bacteria and diseases. Tumors might develop in your cat`s body. This can be prevented by doing regular check ups to the vet.
The primary mode of transmission for FIV is through bite wounds from infected cats. Sexual contact also carries a risk from infecting or getting infected from FIV. That`s why keeping your cat indoors or away from cats that you might think is infected is a good course of action.
Cats tend to be aggressive when they are in heat. As such, they are prone to biting and scratching other cats. Either spay your cats to prevent this kind of aggression, or separate your cat in heat to prevent fighting among them.
Feline Leukemia Virus is one of the most common infectious diseases in cats, affecting between 2-3% of cats in the United States alone. Infection rates are significantly higher (up to 30%) in cats that are ill or otherwise at high risk.
As always, you should always consult your cat`s condition to your vet. As they will tell you the necessary treatment for a cat suffering from FELV.
The only sure way to protect cats from FeLV is to prevent their exposure to FeLV-infected cats. Keeping cats indoors, away from potentially infected cats is recommended. If outdoor access is allowed, provide supervision or place cats in a secure enclosure to prevent wandering and fighting.
Pancreatitis occasionally occurs in the cat. When it does, it is often accompanied by inflammation of the liver and intestine. This multi-organ inflammatory process is sometimes referred to as “triaditis”. This occurs because the inflammation associated with acute pancreatitis allows digestive enzymes to spill into the abdominal cavity.
cats are good at hiding pain, so we need to always assume that pain is present and treat it appropriately (pain causes disease and prevents healing).
Intravenous fluids will be given to maintain normal fluid and electrolyte balance, and analgesics will be given to control the intense pain. Many cases will also require anti-inflammatory drugs, or other medication to control vomiting or diarrhea.
non-steroidal anti-inflammatories (NSAIDs) to reduce inflammation and reduce pain (these are avoided if your cat is dehydrated or has kidney issues).
If the pancreas is unhealthy it doesn`t make a thing called "intrinsic factor" that is needed for vitamin B12 absorption from the diet (deficiency can cause anaemia).
Avoid feeding your cat high-fat meals or table scraps and keep them at a healthy weight.
Bring your cat in for regular wellness visits to check if your cat is developing health-related stuff that you don`t want to worsen.
Hyperthyroidism results when the thyroid gland over-produces thyroid hormones. It’s the most common endocrine disease of cats older than 8-years-old. (An endocrine disease is a disease of the organs that make and secrete hormones.)
When available, radioactive iodine therapy is the treatment of choice for cats with hyperthyroidism. During treatment, radioactive iodine is administered as an injection and is quickly absorbed into the bloodstream. The iodine, which is required for the production of both T3 and T4, is taken up by the thyroid gland and the emitted radiation destroys the abnormal thyroid tissue without damaging the surrounding tissues or the parathyroid glands.
Removal of the thyroid glands, called surgical thyroidectomy, is a relatively straightforward surgical procedure that has a good success rate. The advantage of surgery is that it is likely to produce a long-term or permanent cure in most cats, and therefore eliminates the need for long-term medication.
Anti-thyroid drugs act by reducing the production and release of thyroid hormone from the thyroid gland. These medications do not provide a cure for the disease, but they do allow either short-term or long-term control of hyperthyroidism.
There are currently no known preventive measures for hyperthyroidism, but early diagnosis decreases the secondary problems and improves the prognosis.
// Dog Diseases
Canine Distemper is a disease which is usually caused by a very contagious virus. Puppies and dogs usually become infected through virus particles in the air or in the respiratory secretions of infected dogs.
Sadly, there is no cure for canine distemper. The only way you can treat them is to bring your dog and get it diagnosed in a veterinary clinic; where veterinarians will do their utmost to prevent the worsening of the disease.
Veterinarians will treat your dog with care. They will try to prevent the worsening of the condition by treating the diarrhea, vomiting, and neurological symptoms that your dog may show. They will also try to prevent a secondary infection.
Although there are no cure for canine distemper, there is a vaccine for one. Make sure your dog is vaccinated regularly.
Keep your dog away from infected animals.
This virus is a very dangerous and deadly disease for dogs. It is very contagious and attacks the gastrointestinal system, causing fever, vomiting, and severe, often bloody, diarrhea. It is spread by direct contact between dogs as well as by contaminated stool, surfaces, food bowls, collars, leashes, equipment, and the hands and clothing of people. Treating parvo can be very expensive and many dogs die from parvo despite intensive treatment.
A dog infected with parvo will have diarrhea and will often take a poop or vomit from time-to-time. Keeping your dog hydrated will prevent it from further weakening.
Cleaning after your dog is a must. Every time your dog takes a poop or vomit, sanitize the area where it did its business. This will also prevent your other dogs from contracting the disease.
Hospitalization is needed so medications and fluids can be given through injections. Pets with parvovirus have a very difficult time keeping oral medications. Because of this, home treatment is very difficult to achieve.
By keeping you place clean, you can prevent any might-be-lingering parvo bacteria in your home.
When walking your dog, prevent them from sniffing or getting near a stool in the sidewalk. You don`t know whether the animal which excreted the stool is infected with the parvo or not.
Regularly vaccinate your dog with parvovirus vaccination. This will prevent parvovirus from ever harming your dog.
Heatstroke is a big risk during hot and warm weather. Remember that your dog is always wearing a fur coat and they are usually warmer than you are. A temperature that seems only a little warm to a person can be too hot for a dog. Add to that the fact that dogs are almost always playing and running around.
If you noticed your dog getting weaker or slower, and is having an excessive panting, give your dog a water to hydrate and prevent them from further heating up.
You can wipe your dog`s body with a wet and wrung out towel. Doing this will help them lower the heat they are feeling and refresh them, even if only for a little bit.
When your dog is experiencing intense heat or is already having a heatstroke, take them to the nearest shade you can find. Take shelter and wipe your dog with wet towels or give your dog a water to drink.
By bringing your dog to a vet, veterinarians can treat your dog by giving him IV fluids, oxygen, treatment for shock, and drugs to control the vomiting and other symptoms.
If you feel that your house is unusually hot, cool it off by opening doors and windows. You can also turn on your fan or use your aircon to cool the place. This will help your dog to feel cool and refreshed too, avoiding heatstroke.
Playful dogs that likes to play outside should always have access to shades and water to cool off. It will help them refresh a bit and prevent a heatstroke.
Intestinal Parasites such as roundworms, hookworms, whipworms, and tapeworms lay eggs that are passed in the dog`s stool and infect other dogs when they eat contaminated soil, contaminated water, contaminated food, and when they lick contaminated fur or paws.
If you suspect that your dog is infested with intestinal parasites, get your dog check up to a vet clinic and buy oral medications.
By keeping you place clean, you can prevent any might-be-lingering parasite in your home.
When walking your dog, prevent them from sniffing or getting near a stool in the sidewalk. You don`t know whether the animal which excreted the stool is contaminated with worms or not.
A dog can get infected with leptospirosis by coming into contact with bacteria infected liquids and fluids. Leptospirosis is caused by the bacteria species Leptospira.
Vaccine for leptospirosis have been around since 1970s. By vaccinating your dog, you can prevent them from getting leptospirosis.
As previously mentioned, your dog can get leptospirosis from coming into contact with liquids contaminated with leptospira bacteria. So, by preventing them from coming into contact with suspicious liquids, you can also prevent them from getting infected.
Treatment for leptospirosis is antibiotic therapy, such as the medicines mentioned above. Upon administration, antibiotics immediately inhbits multiplication and replication of the organism, thereby rapidly decreasing the chances of fatal complications.
Heartworms are spread by mosquitoes and can cause coughing, lethargy, difficulty in breathing, and death. Fortunately, there are many approved products to prevent heartworms infection. Consult your veterinarian about the best product for your dog.
Melarsomine is an injectable drug that is commonly used for treating heartworms. It will kill the adult heartworms in the heart and adjacent vessels. This drug is administered in a series of injections. Your veterinarian will determine the specific injection schedule according to your dog`s condition.
Heartworm preventives work by treating heartworms that already infected the pet within the past month or longer; meanwhile, preventives need to be given on time, every time to be effective.
Fungal Organisms in the soil can infect dogs when they eat or sniff contaminated soil. Dogs can also be infected through the skin, especially through an open wound.
There are scientific data to support that vinegar may be beneficial in treating fungal infection. Wash the infected are using a vinegar. It will help by changing the pH of the skin to make it less favorable for fungal infection.
Imitazole is a class of antifungal drugs that is commonly used to treat fungal diseases including Ketaconazole, itraconazole, and Fluconazole. Antifungals are commonly administered directly into the nose.
Washing your dogs from time-to-time or washing them regularly will lower the chances of your dog getting infected by fungal infections.
// Bird Diseases
Salmonella is an infection that can cause ruffled feathers, enlarged eyes, and lethargy in birds. It is mostly disseminated by feces contamination of food and water, but it may also be carried by birds interacting at a busy feeder.
To prevent further growth of salmonella, you can use an antibiotic provided by a veterinary for your bird.
It is required to use the antibiotics prescribes to you by your vet. Or use Antimicrobial Resistant Salmonella bacteria.
To prevent the buildup of Salmonella bacteria and residue, regularly clean your birdbaths. This will prevent the chances of a Salmonella surviving in an environment.
Preventing other birds from having a direct interaction with your bird will prevent an unprecedented infection.
Some mites and lice feed on the feathers and skin of birds, while other feed on blood. Large numbers of blood-sucking mites can cause anemia and mortality in young birds, and a densely infested nest migth force parents to leave their eggs or young.
You can manually remove bird mites from your bird by firmly (but gently) holding your bird, and using a tweezer to pluck any visible mites.
Control Aviary Bug Spray is an excellent solution to keep insects away from bird nests and your home.
Permethrin is a powder extracted from a daisy flower. It is a powder that is mixed in water and sprayed throughout the aviary or as a bird bath to help control the life cycle of the mites.
A bacteria that belongs to taxonomic genus Circovirus. It attacks the feather follicles and the beak and claw matrices of the bird, causing progressive feather, claw and break malformation and necrosis.
By providing your bird a place to clean itself, it can clean any bacteria that might cause feather disease. A clean bird have low chance of getting infected with feather disease.
If by chance your bird refuses to take a bath on a dish of water, you can manually and gently clean your bird by using a soft brush (Toothbrush with soft bristles) and gently brush the body of your bird. Use a shampoo or soap that is prescribed by your vet.
Unfortunately, there is no cure for Feather Disease. But by putting your bird in an intensive care and support, you can prolong its life for at least 1-2 years. Although it is not advised.
This option is only advisable if the condition is dire. This is also advised as to not prolong your bird`s pain and suffering. This will also prevent the disease from spreading to other birds.
Strict hygiene should be followed in bird colonies. Especially controlling the dust. Also, regularly screen for PFBD. Consequently, if any bird is found infected, quarantine the bird and burn its nest box to prevent the disease from spreading.
Pachecho Disease is a highly infected and deadly bird illness. It is caused by the rapidly spreading Herpesvirus and especially affect birds in the Parrot Family. Once infected, the animal may or may not develop symptoms, but usually dies within a few days of contracting the disease.
A medicine called Acyclovir is effective, specially during an outbreak of the disease. Give this to your bird 3 times a day, in 80mg every feed.
A veterinarian will generally prescribe Acyclovir for Pachecho`s disease. However, the medication is known to cause kidney damage and works best during the initial stages of the infection, before the symptoms show.
Pachecho Disease is a highly contagious disease. If one of your bird is infected, it is better off quarantined to prevent it from infecting other birds.
Alternatively, you can quarantine your birds inside to prevent it from catching the disease from infected wild birds outside.
PoxVirus infections belongs to a large DNA viruses that induce intracytoplasmic, lipoliphic bodies (Bollinger Bodies) in the epithelial cells of the integument, respiratory tract, and oral cavity.
Vitamin A plays an important role in avian health and is crucial for a healthy immune system. Hypovitaminosis A causes squamous metaplasia of epithelium within the oropharynx, choana, sinuses, GI tract, urogenital tact, reproductive tract, and uropygial gland as well as hyperkeratosis of the feet.
Antibiotics are medicines that fight infections caused by bacteria in animals by either killing the bacteria or making it difficult for the bacteria to grow and multiply. Bacteria are germs.
Mosquito control and indoor housing are vital to prevent outbreak.
Their are vaccines that can prevent PoxViruses such as Canarypox, Fowlpox, and Pigeonpox.
The West Nile virus is an arthropod-borne virus in the genus Flavivirus. West Nile virus is transmitted to birds through the bite of an infected mosquito. Mosquitoes become infected by biting infected birds. Some birds that are predators (such as hawks and owls) or scavengers (such as crows) may become infected after eating sick or dead birds that were already infected with West Nile virus.
If you live in a country where you know West Nile Virus is spreading, you should vaccinate your bird first thing. By vaccinating your bird, you can prevent it from contracting this virus, making it safe.
After diagnosing your bird, your vet might suggest some actions that will help your bird`s health to improve. Such as IV fluids, antibiotics, and antimicrobials or antifungal.
Rid your house of mosquito to prevent an unprecedented infection. Regularly perform general cleaning to remove any lingering mosquito eggs or mosquitos.
During the mosquito season, birds should be houes indoors or completely covered outdoor facilities. Mosquito netting and mosquito traps should be used, and any standing or stagnat water sources should be eliminated.

A rabbit`s teeth will continually grow throughout its life. If a rabbit is not constantly grinding their teeth down by eating fiber, we start to see their molar teeth forming sharp spikes that damages their cheeks, gums, and tongue. This causes pain that makes them reluctant or unable to eat.
The incisors at the front of the mouth can, in severe cases, grow around in a curl; meaning rabbits cannot close their mouth or eat at all. If left untreated, Overgrown teeth can cause a rabbit to greatly suffer or worse, die.
Chewing on a well made toy helps your rabbit keep its teeth/molars well-trimmed. A chew toy can prevent a growing molars on its early stages or prevent it from growing at a dangerous length at all.
This method, although is not advised, can prevent molars to grow to dangerous length. It involves a regular dog nail clippers to cut the teeth as you would cut toe nails. But as mentioned before, it is not advised not to use this method as there is a high risk of cracking or splitting the tooth because of the force needed to use the clippers.
The third method is to use a handheld rotary tool, like a Dremel or a Dental bur, to slice the excess tooth off. This method requires care and skill and sometimes require an anaesthesia or sedation to keep a rabbit still. This method causes no trauma to the teeth and nerve. The only concerns are possible trauma to the gums or lips if the cutting tool accidentally grazes them or if a tooth is trimmed too short.
To start, a complete endroscopic oral exam is carried out. Inspection of the oral activity is performed to locate the drainage point of the abscess. The space between teeth (periodontal pockets) are probed for signs of the periodontitis.
Pus surrounding a tooth or increased laxity (looseness of a tooth) would indicate that would indicate that the extraction of the tooth is necessary. Molar spurs (sharp points) are removed with a high speed hand drill. Teeth that are crooked or too tall are also reduced in height in the process called down reduction.
After the completion of the intra-oral dental work, the abscess is then addresses. Often times, the abscess is most easily accessible from the outside, through the skin. Using a scalpel, that abscess is lanced and thoroughly drained. Any non-living unhealthy tissue associated with the abscess is excised.
80-90% of your rabbit`s diet need to be fiber in the form of oaten or grass hay. The rest of the diet should be leafy greens, with pellets and other treats being minimal to non-existent.
Close contact with an infected rabbit can easily transfer the Pasteurella multocida bacterium to your rabbit. The bacteria can affect the eyes (discharge, redness, squinting) and/or nose (sneezing, discharge), thus giving the disease its name `snuffles`.
Pasteurella can infect other areas of the body as well, including ears (resulting in a head tilt),abscesses (seen as lumps on the body) and uterine infections.
To prevent clogged nose or snotty eyes, use a soft cloth or a tissue damped with warm water. Do this regularly and get your rabbit to the vet when it gets worse.
Antibiotics is always the go to solution to treat bacterial infections. But before you gibe your rabbit antibiotics, make sure to consult your vet first about the perfect antibiotics to use for your rabbit`s condition.
Nebuliser can also help to soothe your rabbit`s airways and ease its breathing.
Vets suggest to use Anti-Inflammatory Pain Relief (NSAIDs) to treat pain, inflammation, and high fevers.
As always, keeping your pet away from infected animals / pets is the best way to prevent them from getting infected. Quarantine your infected rabbit or take it to a vet clinic to get treated.
Any cage or bedding that has come into contact with infected rabbits should be properly sanitized or replaced. After sanitizing and disinfecting cages and bedding, thoroughly clean yourself too to prevent spreading the bacteria.
Uterine adenocarcinoma, a gland-like, malignant type of tumor that arises from the secretory tissue that lines the inner cavity of the uterus, is one of the most common forms of cancer in rabbits, occurring in up to 60 percent of female rabbits over three years old.
These malignant uterine tumors usually arise from the endometrial lining of the uterus, or from the inside layers of the uterus.
These malignant uterine tumors usually arise from the endometrial lining of the uterus, or from the inside layers of the uterus.
Adenocarcinoma may involve a complete hysterectomy to remove the diseased parts of your rabbit’s organs. This is usually the primary treatment, especially if the cancer has not spread beyond the reproductive organs.
Is a common surgery performed on female rabbits, the medical term is an ovariohysterectomy (removal of ovaries and uterus), abbreviated as an OVH.
Is a common surgery performed on female rabbits, the medical term is an ovariohysterectomy (removal of ovaries and uterus), abbreviated as an OVH.
Since uterine cancer is seen only in intact females, prevention by means of spaying is highly recommended. If rabbits are being bred, it is recommended to halt breeding and spay before they reach 4 years. This method of prevention will also reduce the risk of mammary cancer.
Rabbits are masters of reproducing. A single pair of rabbits could theoretically produce 185,000,000,000 descendants in just 7 years. And as such, issues are bound to arise.
Uterine tumours are issue within their wombs and reproductive tracts; therefore, spaying your rabbits at an early age is a sure way to prevent them from growing uterine tumours.
Myxomatosis is a virus that is transmitted by mosquitoes, fleas or by close contact between an infected rabbit and a susceptible rabbit. The disease is recognised by swelling and discharge from the eyes, nose and anogenital region.
Myxomatosis is a virus that belongs to the PoxVirus. The best way to prevent your rabbit from getting this virus is to vaccinate it regularly.
Currently there is no exact treatment for the disease, but supportive care can be provided to ease the symptoms. Rabbits with myxomatosis are given fluids, pain medication, and antibiotics, which will aid and prevent further infections.
One of the carriers of this deadly virus are Fleas. By making sure that your house is free of fleas, you can ensure the safety of your rabbit.
Mosquitoes also carry this virus. Make sure that your house is also free from mosquitoes. Especially at dawn or dusk, when mosquito levels are higher.
Hair can normally be found in a rabbit’s stomach as they self-groom. However, as rabbits cannot vomit, hair must be able to pass through the gut. If it can’t then it will form an obstruction and serious complications.
Hairballs are so common that they should always be considered as a problem in any rabbit that is lethargic and not eating.
Brushing every day or every other day prevents the formation of hairballs in the stomach. They do not tolerate excessive cold or heat.
The space for your cage or house should be located away from drafts and should have a container for hay, a waterer, a feeder, a place to shelter and a corner. Always have a first aid kit for rabbits.
Sometimes surgery is the only treatment if the hairball causes a blockage in the gut. Medication to get the gut working again can also help.
Hairballs are more likely to become a problem if there is an issue with the gastrointestinal tract (gut stasis) or they are not receiving enough fiber in their diet, so a high fiber diet is a great preventative measure.
Rabbit Haemorrhagic Disease Virus (previously known as Rabbit Calicivirus) is spread by mosquitoes, flies and/or through indirect contact or direct contact with an infected rabbit.
In most adult rabbits the disease progresses rapidly from fever and lethargy to sudden death within 48-72 hours of infection. The incubation period for the RHDV is between one to three days. Most rabbits will show no signs of external symptoms of RHDV.
Rabbit haemorrhagic disease has no treatment, but its symptoms can be managed. Although it is very difficult to eradicate in wild rabbits, it is achieved in domestic rabbits with biosecurity measures such as:
• Hygiene and frequent disinfection of their space.
• Elimination and extermination of affected rabbits.
• Strict quarantine when infection is confirmed.
• Vaccination prevention where possible.
• Good ventilation of their hutch.
• Protective nets (if they have access to the garden).
• Prevent the access of rodents or wild rabbits.
• Epidemiological surveillance with sentinel rabbits.
• Disinfection, deratization and disinfection program.
Vaccinating your rabbit will help provide protection against RHDV1. Vaccinations are administered every 6 months for adult rabbits. Adult rabbits that are overdue for a vaccination or have not previously been vaccinated will need to be given two vaccinations, one month apart.
Young rabbit kittens can be vaccinated from four weeks of age repeated monthly until 12 weeks of age and then every six months.
// Frog Diseases Description
Chytridiomycosis is a disease causing precipitous declines in frog and salamander populations on a global scale. There are two fungi responsible for this disease: Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) and Batrachochytrium salamandivorans (Bsal).
Antifungal medications are used to treat fungal infections. How it works is that the medication kills the fungal cells that are slowly spreading around your frog`s skin.
Giving your frog a salt bath (50 to 100 grams of sea salt per gallon) fir fifteen to thirty minutes everyday will help prevent the spreading of the fungal infection in its skin.
Chytridiomycosis is vulnerable to heat and will often die at temperatures above 32 degree celsius. Increasing the temperature of your frog`s housing will help kill this fungal infection and stop its spread.
Control of chytridiomycosis in amphibian colonies includes disinfection of enclosures and implementation of husbandry practices that prevent cross-contamination of enclosures with water or substrate material.
The infectious zoospores are sensitive to desiccation, and to date, no resting stages resistant to drying have been identified.
Red-leg syndrome is a widespread infection seen in frogs, toads, and salamanders. It is recognized by the redness on the underside of the amphibian`s legs and abdomen, and is generally due to Aeromonas hydrophila, an opportunistic bacterial pathogen.
However, viruses and fungi may also cause similar reddening. Underfed, newly acquired amphibians that are kept in poor-quality water or other less-than-ideal environmental conditions are particularly susceptible to red-leg syndrome.
Clean the injured area with sterile gauze soaked in normal saline or clean water. Do not use cotton wool or any material material that will fray or leave fluff in the wound.
Apply an appropriate dressing such as a band aid or a non-adhesive dressing held in place with a hypoallergenic tape.
Treating “red-leg” syndrome will depend on the underlying cause of the disease. For example, if it is due to the Aeromonas hydrophila bacterium, your veterinarian will prescribe antibiotics for the amphibian.
Follow the guidelines set by your veterinarian to get optimum results.
Maintaining a clean, hygienic living environment for the amphibian will go a long way toward preventing “red-leg” syndrome. As such, tanks should be cleaned regularly, so as to prevent organic matter from collecting.
Generally referred to as obesity, excess body weight is as much a problem in amphibians as it is in humans. This nutritional disorder puts a strain on and taxes many of the body organs, even resulting in death some cases.
Limiting your frog`s feeding session is the only way to control its diet. Don`t overfeed a frog as it will cause it to gain excessive wait that might lead to obesity.
Enlarge the amphibian’s living area or enclosure. Increasing the animal’s activity will improve its metabolic rate, allowing it to burn excess calories.
Maintaining the amphibian at the upper end of its preferred temper¬ature range will also accelerate metabolic rate and increase caloric use.
However, care should be taken to never exceed the maximum recom¬mended temperature for the amphibian species. Lastly, reducing the amount of food given to an animal will help with many nutritional disorders, including obesity.
Although overfeeding can easily lead to an obese amphibian, monitoring the animal’s food consumption and allowing it to forage and stalk its food will help rectify the situation. Also, consult with your veterinarian to establish a proper nutritional plan for your amphibian.
Amphibians are susceptible to infection by many bacteria, of which several are atypical Mycobacteria. Mycobacteria are microscopic organisms present everywhere in nature.
And while amphibians are naturally resistant to mycobacterial infections, a diminished or compromised immunity due to malnutrition, disease or stress, among other things, can make the animal more prone to the infection.
Mycobacteriosis is a contagious disease that can be passed as a skin infection from animals to humans (or a zoonotic infection). Therefore, precaution must be taken while handling an infected amphibian.
Treat with ENROFLOXACIN (BAYTRIL) Put 8 drops in 125ml Tepid water. Put a lid on the bowl and make sure the frogs’ head stays above the water. Duration: 15 min. each day for 6 days.
Unfortunately, there is no available treatment for this disease. However, the veterinarian may prescribe antibiotics to treat any other secondary bacterial infection.
The best defense for Mycobacteriosis is prevention. Mycobacteria typically live in the slime layer that builds up in aquatic habitats over time. For this reason, weekly cleaning and removal of this film is recommended.

Lizards and other reptiles are prone to ear infections. A bulging ear drum, pus around the ears and pain when the mouth is opened are all key ear infection symptoms.
Head shaking and general sensitivity around the ears are other clues.
Surgery is required to remove the hardened pus from an aural abscess, but this is rarely life threatening. This the most effective and safest means of treating it.
Antibiotic ear drops are generally used to treat a bacterial ear infection, also known as bacterial otitis externa. Topical preparations are available as single medications or as combinations; common antibiotic preparations include neomycin, gentamicin, polymyxin B, enrofloxacin and silver sulfadiazine.
The surfaces of the habitat should be kept very clean, with water and food bowls changed out and disinfected every few days. Chemicals should not be used. Environmental humidity and temperature should also be carefully monitored.

Antibiotics work well against treating bacteria. There are a number of antibiotics that you can give your pet reptile, but a consultation from a vet will do your reptile more good.
Make sure that the food that you are feeding your reptile is safe from the bacteria. Buy your food from well-known shops that serves food for reptiles.
Cleaning your reptile`s cage regularly is a must. A well-cleaned aquarium or cage for your reptile will help clear out any lingering disease causing bacteria.

A balanced diet with adequate amounts of vitamin D and calcium and an adequate amount of physical activity are needed for normal bone metabolism.
More formally called stomatitis, this disease is caused by bad diet as well as poor temperature and humidity conditions in a reptile`s habitat. Mouth sores or infected tissues will develop, and in severe cases, surgery may be required.
If your reptile`s mouth suddenly starts showing smal patches of darkening skin, you can start by gently cleaning it. Cleaning it with Q-tip with a solution prescribed by your vet.
Antibiotics and a thorough cleaning of your pet’s mouth will likely follow. In severe cases, surgery might be required to remove dead or intensely damaged oral tissue.
Make sure your reptile’s diet is a quality and healthy one. Keep the terrarium environment clean with weekly disinfecting sessions and daily checks for dirty spots or uneaten food.

Vets usually prescribe Oral Medications that will be regularly taken by your reptile. For more information, take your reptile to the nearest vet clinic.
Another treatment that your vet will likely suggest is antiviral medicines for the infection. The medication can either be ointment (for application on mouth sores), or oral medicine (for generic treatment of the disease).
To prevent the Herpesvirus from spreading, the pet reptile`s habitat needs to be thoroughly disinfected.
These can happen as a result of bacterial grown from living in damp conditions, for some reptiles this is the correct environment but that doesn’t mean to say it shouldn’t be monitored.
The skin will become damp, weak and damaged. It’s a good idea to try an anti-fungal spray which is specially designed for reptiles or consult your specialist exotics vet.
Antifungal creams will slowly help the recovery of your reptile`s skin. Antifungal creams and ointments are effective against common fungal bacterias.
Antibiotic treatment is usually recommended following surgery to prevent any secondary infection.
Good sanitation and a well-balanced diet may decrease the incidents of fungal diseases in reptiles.

Loose, watery and possibly more-frequent bowel movements — is a common problem. It may be present alone or be associated with other symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain or weight loss. Luckily, diarrhea is usually short-lived, lasting no more than a few days.
Diarrhea will most of the time dehydrate your pet hamster. So, making sure that your hamster is drinking water regularly is the first thing you need to do when it`s experiencing diarrhea.
Your veterinarian will diagnose your hamster and will likely put it under a fluid administration treatment to counter the dehydration caused by the diarrhea.
Sick hamsters should be kept separate from other hamsters to prevent spreading the illness, and the cages of both the sick and healthy animals should be thoroughly cleaned and sanitized.
Keep your hamster cage away from drafts (such as by windows and doors) and in an area with a consistently warm temperature as this will be a way for algae build up in your hamster`s water bottle.
Arterial thrombosis is the formation of a thrombus within an artery. In most cases, arterial thrombosis follows rupture of atheroma (a fat-rich deposit in the blood vessel wall), and is therefore referred to as atherothrombosis. Arterial embolism occurs when clots then migrate downstream and can affect any organ.
There is no known effective treatment to treat Atrial Thrombosis. Hamsters with this disease usually dies one week after showing signs.
Veterinarians will likely use a medicine called thrombolytic which can dissolve some blood clots.
Atrial Thrombosis usually occur with hamsters of old age. The best prevention for this disease is to give them a healthy diet to lower the chances of acquiring this illness.
Tyzzer’s disease is an acute epizootic bacterial disease found in rodents, rabbits, dogs, cats, birds, pandas, deer, foals, cattle, and other mammals including gerbils. It is caused by the spore-forming bacterium Clostridium piliforme, formerly known as Bacillus
Your veterinarian will often treat Tyzzer`s disease by administering broad-spectrum antibiotic drugs. He or she may also prescribe vitamin and mineral supplements to help improve the health status and immunity of the infected hamsters.
If the hamster is dehydrated, fluids and electrolyte supplements may be administered.
Routinely cleaning the hamster`s living area and separating healthy hamsters from those suspected of infection are two good ways of preventing the spread of Tyzzer`s disease.
Salmonella infection (salmonellosis) is a common bacterial disease that affects the intestinal tract. Salmonella bacteria typically live in animal and human intestines and are shed through feces.
Broad-spectrum antibiotic drugs and supportive therapy with fluids and electrolyte supplements may be used, but only in mild cases.
A hamster recovering from salmonella infection will be weak and require your extra care. Consult your veterinarian regarding the hamster`s diet and medication regimen. However, use extreme caution while handling infected hamsters, as there is a chance you may contract the Salmonella infection from your pet.
almonella infection is highly contagious and is mainly transmitted in hamsters through ingestion of food and water contaminated with infected feces, urine and bedding material. Therefore, regularly cleaning the cages and removing feces, urine, and soiled bedding material is essential.
In addition, remove any hamster suspected of being infected to avoid an outbreak.
Tapeworm infection is caused by ingesting food or water contaminated with tapeworm eggs or larvae. If you ngest certain tapeworm eggs, they can migrate outside your intestines and form larval cysts in body tissues and organs (invasive infection).
Endoparasitic infection is easily treatable and several specially formulated anthelminthic drugs are available to kill tapeworms.
Hamsters with a heavy endoparasitic infection or those that have gone undiagnosed for a long time may require fluid and electrolyte therapy. Your veterinarian may also recommend giving the hamster vitamin and mineral supplements to improve the animal`s body condition.
In addition to maintaining proper sanitation techniques, bringing the hamster to your veterinarian for regular deworming appointments is the best way of preventing incidences of tapeworm infections.
Pneumonia, or inflammation of the lungs, is not usually encountered in hamsters. When it does occur, it is typically the result of an infection with one or more kinds of bacteria, sometimes in conjunction with viruses or other types of infectious agents.
These infections are especially hard for the hamster to fight off when there are stress-inducing changes to the environment, such as a sudden change in room temperature.
Unfortunately, treatment is not effective in severe cases of pneumonia. Hamsters with mild cases of pneumonia, meanwhile, respond well to treatment, though this typically involves treating the signs rather than the condition itself. For example, oxygen therapy may be administered to help the animal breathe easier.
However, if the pneumonia is caused by a bacterial infection, your veterinarian will likely prescribe long-term antibiotics.
It is vital that you remove any pneumonic hamsters from the healthy animals to prevent the spread of infection. Keep those that are infected in a calm and clean area so that they may rest.
Avoid overcrowding the cages and keep them warm, dry, and free of soiled bedding material.
// Guinea Pig String Block
Pneumonia, the clinical name given to inflammation of the lungs, is the most frequent cause of death in guinea pigs. It is also a contagious condition in groups of guinea pigs.
In general, treatment for guinea pigs will consist of alleviating the symptoms rather than for the pneumonia itself. The main goal is to support the body so that it can recover form the diseased condition.
Supportive therapy with fluids may be necessary in cases of dehydration due to appetite loss, oxygen therapy may be needed to help with respiratory distress, and administration of vitamin C may be needed to help improve your guinea pig`s immune system and ward off opportunistic infections.
Properly cleaning the cages, changing soiled bedding material, and regularly removing feces and urine and routinely is essential for the prevention of pneumonia, and for keeping infections under control when they do occur.
Guinea pigs have a sensitive gastrointestinal tract (as do rabbits). They have a very specific natural population of "good" gastrointestinal bacteria (flora) critical to normal bowel function.
If this normal bacterial flora becomes altered or unbalanced, `bad` (often gas-producing) bacteria can overgrow, produce painful gas, slow down digestion and food passage through the intestinal tract, damage the intestinal tissues, release toxins, cause severe diarrhea, and in severe cases, death.
Whenever your pet has a diarrhea, the first thing you should do is always take it to the vet to check for underlying illness. But for the meantime, give your guinea pig a source of hydration. Water bowls, water bottles, etc. Diarrhea can be very dehydrating for animals.
If your pet refuses to drink water, take it to the vet for IV Fluid treatment. Antibiotics may be necessary if the diarrhea is caused by bacterial infection.
Ensuring that adequate roughage is included in your pet’s diet can prevent diet-related diarrhea. Diarrhea due to an infection, on the other hand, may be prevented by keeping the guinea pig`s bedding, water bottle, and living environment clean and sanitized; promptly removing uneaten food before it rots can also reduce the level of disease-causing organisms.
Guinea pigs and primates cannot manufacture their own vitamin C; therefore, they must take in vitamin C in their diets. The majority of other animals can produce their own vitamin C through their intestinal bacterial and maintenance of skin, joints, and mucosal surfaces, such as the gums. It is also important in the healing of wounds.
Scurvy is a Vitamin C defficiency. As such, the prescribed medications and treatment will involve your Guinea Pig taking in Vitamin C medications and food.
Pain relief medication will often be given to make your guinea pig more comfortable. Some cases of Scurvy are very serious and can result in other damage to the body which needs additional treatment and procedures, and in some cases if not treated soon enough Scurvy can be fatal.
The best way to prevent Scurvy is to ensure you feed your guinea pigs a balanced diet high in vitamin C. Commercial guinea pig pellets contain vitamin C but should only be fed in small amounts. So the rest of your guinea pigs vitamin C needs to come from fresh fruit and vegetables.
Infected swelling containing an accumulation of pus and bacteria can affect lymph nodes, skin, muscles, teeth, bones, and internal organs. Since guinea pigs and other rodents and rabbits form thick pus that does not drain or get reabsorbed easily, most abscesses in these animals require surgical removal debridement, followed by treatment with antibiotics chosen based on culture of the bacteria growing in the abscess.
The affected area is flushed with sterile saline and/or antimicrobial solutions, which are solutions that kill or suppress the growth of the microorganisms.
urgical removal of affected tissues or surgically opening the abscess are the most common treatments.
Keep sharp objects away from your guinea pig and keep his living area clean and sanitized. Avoid contact between guinea pigs and other animals that may result in puncture wounds from teeth or nails.
Guinea pigs are very prone to development of urinary calculi stones or uroliths. These stones most often form in the bladder but may also form in the kidneys or ureters tubes that drain the kidneys into the bladder. Stones may become lodged in the ureter or the urethra the tube carrying urine from the bladder to the outside, causing a life-threatening obstruction.
Important to encourage water intake by using different forms of environmental enrichment by always providing fresh and clean water and offer more than one bottle of water in their cage. Fruit or vegetable infusions can be used such as cucumber or watermelon.
Veterinarians will prescribe antibiotics such as enrofloxacin, meloxicam for a couple of days or weeks, depending on the severity. Antibiotics depend on the strain present in your guinea pig’s bladder or urinary tract.
There are many things you can do to help prevent a guinea pig, especially a female which are more vulnerable to this disease. Make sure the hairs around the genitals (anus and vagina or penis) are kept short and cleaned.
Pododermatitis is a condition in which a guinea pig’s footpad becomes inflamed, develops sores, or becomes overgrown. The appearance may be similar to callouses, or small tumors on the bottom of the foot. This condition is commonly referred to as bumblefoot.
When bumblefoot is left untreated or is present in a very severe form, there are sometimes complications in treatment and the infected leg may have to be amputated.
An effective way to treat bumblefoot is to soak the affected area in a solution of warm water and Epsom salts. You need to supervise your cavy at all times during this process, as the salt can get in its eye. Do this two to three times a day.
If the condition needs medical treatment beyond simple environmental changes, your veterinarian will provide this. Your veterinarian will clean the wounds, clip the hair around the infected areas, and trim any overgrown nails and dead tissue on the feet. Soaking the feet in antibiotic solutions may also prove to be useful.
In severe cases, guinea pigs may need oral antibiotics and pain medications. You may also need to keep the feet bandaged, with fresh dressings and topical antibiotics applied regularly to encourage healing. Prolonged, untreated cases where pododermatitis has worsened to severe infection that is not responding to immediate treatment may require amputation of the infected leg.
Providing cages with smooth bottoms for your guinea pigs, keeping the floors clean and dry, and treating any injuries immediately can help prevent pododermatitis from occurring. Because this is a relatively common ailment, guinea pig owners are advised to check their pets` feet daily, including the length of the nails, and watching the guinea pig`s weight and making dietary changes as needed.
